titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Multimedia material, Accessions 2017:081 and 2017:084
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Multimedia material, Accessions 2017:081 and 2017:084 FA1406
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-11-01 04:21:25 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Multimedia material, Accessions 2017:081 and 2017:084

physdesc.extent: 17 boxes (14 letter document containers, 2 legal document containers, and 1 16x20 oversize box)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series:
Series 1: Project Photographs and Foundation-Assigned Photograph Commissions
Series 2: Office of Communications â€“ General Photographs

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2017 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2017:081 and Accession 2017:084.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

The Foundation's efforts in the field of communications have focused primarily on clarifying policy issues, advancing competence in journalism, and improving the system of public broadcasting in the United States. The Foundation's work in communications also aims to convey the lessons learned from its work and to counter the notion that societal problems are intractable.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains prints, negatives, transparencies, slides, and contact sheets that document Ford Foundation projects around the world as well as headshots of staff, executive officers, and trustees for the Ford Foundation's Office of Communications. Many photographs appear in annual reports and other Ford Foundation publications and promotional materials.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Photographic Collection, No. 1300-1356
